nodes.bodyText:
Configuring this feature should not require users to edit Spring bean definitions.  (Spring bean level configurations should really be reserved for advanced configurations which most users need not touch.)
I'd recommend this be enabled/disabled via a configuration in stats.cfg (so it can be overridden in local.cfg) in the same (or similar) way to Google Analytics (and the GoogleRecorderEventListener in this same Spring XML config).

nodes.bodyText:
Also, this property looks to me like it should be marked @Inject or @Autowired instead of configured, since it likely will never be REconfigured.  I would expect that we'd have a different implementation of EventService, if this had to change, because it would be changing for all dependents.  But that's a guess....
@tdonohue we need to work out and write down guidance on how we all expect to see DI used in DSpace and how to classify configuration (including bean wiring).  Not here of course, but somewhere prominent.

nodes.bodyText: @mwoodiupui : Agreed on writing this down better...I simply haven't had time (and I welcome collaboration on this if you are interested).  But, yes, @Autowired could make sense here, and I prefer that for things not needing to be touched.  Spring bean XML is ok for things that might need touching, but only for advanced configs (though quite honestly, I prefer @Autowired where possible to do so, and I've tried to keep Spring XML entirely out of the new dspace-server-webapp).  Finally, *.cfg configs is for things that require extra configuration or for enabling/disabling features (even enabling/disabling OAI-PMH, SWORD,etc is now in *.cfg files as of DSpace 7).

The latest master is also merged into the PR, with a few changes to work with java 11 and mockito.

nodes.bodyText: This configuration (dspace.url) no longer exists in DSpace 7.  I suspect it should be the dspace.ui.url here.  But, be aware that the URL you are building in this method will not exist in the new DSpace UI.  However, it likely should be redirected to the new Bitstream URL automatically.
Updated the url to the new one.

FYI dspace.hostname config no longer exists in our configuration.  It has no replacement as there is no longer a guarantee of a single hostname.  For OAI-PMH urls though, we now use a oai.identifier.prefix configuration, which likely is what you want here. There is also now a Utils.getHostname() method that can be used based on a passed in URL.  See the changes made in PR #2657
Similar to above, the url was changed
I don't understand the string splitting going on here.  We should add a comment to describe it

It appears that the value of trackerType will look like some.thing or some.thing.else.  It might be clearer to split it once into a temporary and then just pass the elements of the temporary to #getMetadata.  But it still needs comments.
The compiler's dataflow analyzer may understand that it can elide the second, third, and fourth identical split calls and re-use its own temporary, but why not make this explicit and clear?
This should be more clear now in the code
Again, dspace.url doesn't exist anymore.  This likely should be dspace.ui.url
Updated the url
This service doesn't appear to be specific to IRUS.  It's an OpenURL service right?

nodes.bodyText:
We do not tend to camel-case our database tables (see other database tables). I'd prefer this be called either openurltracker or openurl_tracker.
These changes should be synced with Postgres & Oracle SQL scripts

nodes.bodyText: Can we just Autowired these services instead of having to init them in a more manual fashion?  This entire method seems like it may not be necessary if we use annotations.
Since the processor is not a bean itself, the services could not be autowired. Changed the init to use the factories in declaration.

The name of this SQL file is odd to me.  Here we use the term "harvester", but the table is a "tracker" and doesn't seem to be harvesting from anything.  Should this SQL file be renamed?  It also likely should reference to ticket under which it was created.  So, it might be named something like V7.0_2020.01.08__DS-626-statistics-tracker.sql or similar.
Changed the name of the file

This doesn't need to be added. It can be initialized in the tests using configurationService.setProperty() rather than adding it here.  Adding it here has global effect (across all tests) when we only need it for a few

nodes.bodyText: Just a note: You don't need to mock a config setting. You can just set it using configurationService.setProperty().  Configs reload after every test.
Removed the mocking of these properties, and set them in the class instead
Same here, no need to mock a configuration. Just set it in each method or have a @Before
Same as above
Same as above
Updated this as well
dspace.hostname is not valid.  Again here, you should not need to mock configurations. Just set them to the values you need.
Updated the config parameter
These services should be all @Autowired and definitely should NOT be static. We tend to avoid static unless it's a constant and these are not.
Removed the static, but as mentioned before due to the class not being a bean, the factories were used to initialise the services
Again, no need to mock configurations
Updated config

We should never close/complete/abort a Context which is created from another method.  Please refactor this class to create the Context in this internalRun() method instead of caching a global Context object (see other DSpaceRunnable scripts as examples).
Just as an FYI.  The reason this is dangerous is that if we are reusing a Context over several methods, it's possible either the Context never gets closed (which leaves open DB connections forever), or possible it gets closed too soon (in which case other methods using the same Context will throw errors).  So, our best practice is to either:

Pass the Context object as a param between methods
Or, get a new Context in each method & close that new Context once the method is done with it.
Moved the context creation to be inside the internalRun() method

Tiny thing. This class doesn't seem specific to IRUS.  Is it specific to IRUS?  If so, we should rename it to include IRUS in the name.  If not, then we should correct these comments to make it clear that, while this class can be used for IRUS, it's not specific to IRUS.
Since this class exports usage events to IRUS, it is specific to IRUS. Updated the name of the class.

Does it matter to IRUS that this Bitstream download URL might end up being at a different hostname from the DSpace UI?   This might be perfectly OK for IRUS, but I just wanted to call out the fact that dspace.server.url and dspace.ui.url may be entirely different servers/hosts/origins.  If that has an impact on IRUS, we may want to change this getBitstreamInfo() method to give a valid dspace.ui.url for downloading the Bitstream (which would just redirect to the REST API obviously).
If we've verified that IRUS doesn't care about this, then no need to worry about it.  I just wanted to add a comment as I noticed that some URLs we pass to IRUS are using dspace.ui.url (e.g. the Item URLs from ItemEventProcessor), while this one uses dspace.server.url.

NOTE: You don't need to cache all these Configuration properties globally.  Doing that means that a site cannot modify these configurations without having to restart Tomcat.
Usually, we simply load the configuration when we need it... as that ensures it is read at that point in time from the ConfigurationService, and modifying the value in your local.cfg therefore does NOT require restarting Tomcat.  This is the preferred behavior, so I'd recommend removing this initProperties() entirely, unless you have a real reason for caching these properties in this class
(Keep in mind, the ConfigurationService already does its own caching to ensure it performs well...so there's no need to cache these settings for better performance.)
UPDATE: I think if you fix this, your tests will work better. I noticed a lot of your tests are strangely having to pass the ConfigurationService back to the EventProcessor. This should never be necessary if you simply load the Configurations dynamically instead of caching them in the class.

If you inspect random DSpace classes, you will indeed see configuration properties being loaded at construction or even statically, and kept forever.  That pattern worked well with ConfigurationManager, but it's a poor use of ConfigurationService (one that I'm trying to forget).
Updated the config to be loaded where needed.
This Connection never seems to be closed? I think we need to close the connection here after getting the responseCode.
The connection is now disconnected after reading the status result
Please update init() to use Builder classes (which have now moved to dspace-api...see #2897.  That will allow you to simplify the destroy() method.
Updated the tests to use the Builder classes.

Just a note.  There's an assertEquals() method instead of assertThat(..., is())  There's also an assertTrue() instead of assertThat(... is(true)).  Those alternatives are a bit easier to read.  But, if you'd rather just use assertThat() everywhere, that's OK.
I changed the asserts to be more specific and readable.

This line is unnecessary.  The bitstreamEventProcessor already has access to the ConfigurationService (which is a global service)  You don't need to change it's value.  In fact, this shouldn't be allowed...we should make the configurationService (and all services) private in the EventProcessors.

This was necessary originally due the EventProcessor being a mock object where the configuration service did not get initialised.
Due to the other changes to the Objects and tests, this is no longer an issue.

Again, don't change the services in your Processer. That's not needed.  These lines all must be removed.
This same flaw exists in all tests in this class.
Keep in mind, the Context and Request can be modified via the constructor. So you should use the Constructor here to modify them.
Same as above

This should be set via configurationService.setProperty("stats.tracker.urlversion", "Z39.88-2004") instead of modifying the class directly.  That'd make this test better as it ensures the configuration is working properly.
Set the configuration in the configuration service
These services should all be private.  You should not allow service sharing between classes, as all of these Services can be reloaded globally where needed.
Made the services private. As a consequence I could no longer easily mock them so the tests have been updated to use the real services instead.
Again, as noted before, don't do this.  It's not a best practice to change services in other classes, even in tests.
Same as above.
If possible, these should also be made private so that you are forced to use the Constructor (see below) to change them.  We should not allow changing them after the class has been initialized.
Made the variables private
@YanaDePauw : These variables still appear to be protected and not private as you stated above.

Since this entire file is specific to IRUS, we should rename it to be irus-statistics.cfg and prefix all settings with irus.statistics.tracker (instead of stats.tracker).
This would bring it more in line with the other stats config files: usage-statistics.cfg and solr-statistics.cfg.  Naming this just stats.cfg would likely be confusing to users.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,35 @@
+# Enable the IRUS tracker. By default or when omitted, the tracker will be disabled
+stats.tracker.enabled = false

nodes.bodyText: I updated the variables and changed the IRUS property names to contain IRUS and be less generic
